Award.AbstractNarration:
This project centers on the analysis of div-curl systems of equations and on the solution of partial differential equations with physical boundary conditions in 3 dimensional regions. Such systems arise as mathematical models of wide classes of problems in continuum mechanics and electromagnetic field theories. Particular attention will be paid to describing solvability conditions and the approximation and representation of weak solutions of these systems. Some of the novelty involves the careful choice of scalar and vector potentials for these problems and the use of Steklov eigenfunctions to describe the effects of boundary data. Another class of problems is the development of variational principles that characterize solutions of initial value problems for evolution equations.

The analysis performed under this award should help in the development of computational simulations and the numerical approximation of solutions to many important equations arising in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided support for the development of new mathematical results about problems that arise in classical field theories. That is to say, results were obtained about functions and fields that satisfy equations arising in certain  electromagnetic or fluid mechanical problems.

        Many of the results aimed at showing how the solutions of various problems depend on boundary conditions. In many cases new formulae for, and representations of,  the solutions are found. It is expected that these will be of interest and use in the approximation and computational simulation of solutions. 

        The results often centered on the use of Steklov eigenproblems to solve various boundary value problems. Some new trace results about the properties of functions and fields on the boundaries of regions were proved.

        Of particular interest are the new results about Green's functions for elliptic boundary value problems. Formulae are given for Green's functions  in terms of the fundamental solution and certain Steklov expansions. Another major result was the determination of the singular value decomposition of the Poisson kernel. The Poisson kernel represents the solution of Dirichlet problems for Laplace's equation on a region and has been studied extensively. I showed that under mild conditions on the boundary, it is a compact linear transformation from a Hilbert space of functions on the boundary to the harmonic Bergman space of L^2 functions on a region. The singular values and singular vectors of this problem were shown to be the Steklov eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of a problem for the biharmonic operator.

          This award also helped support the research work of four students who graduated with doctoral degrees and one who is expected to graduate soon under my supervision.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2016
Modified by: Giles Auchmuty
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This award provided support for the development of new mathematical results about problems that arise in classical field theories. That is to say, results were obtained about functions and fields that satisfy equations arising in certain electromagnetic or fluid mechanical problems. Many of the results aimed at showing how the solutions of various problems depend on boundary conditions. In many cases new formulae for, and representations of, the solutions are found. It is expected that these will be of interest and use in the approximation and computational simulation of solutions. The results often centered on the use of Steklov eigenproblems to solve various boundary value problems. Some new trace results about the properties of functions and fields on the boundaries of regions were proved. Of particular interest are the new results about Green's functions for elliptic boundary value problems. Formulae are given for Green's functions in terms of the fundamental solution and certain Steklov expansions. Another major result was the determination of the singular value decomposition of the Poisson kernel. The Poisson kernel represents the solution of Dirichlet problems for Laplace's equation on a region and has been studied extensively. I showed that under mild conditions on the boundary, it is a compact linear transformation from a Hilbert space of functions on the boundary to the harmonic Bergman space of L^2 functions on a region. The singular values and singular vectors of this problem were shown to be the Steklov eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of a problem for the biharmonic operator. This award also helped support the research work of four students who graduated with doctoral degrees and one who is expected to graduate soon under my supervision.
